user_input: What is the swath width of the Sentinel-2 SAR instrument?
retrieved_contexts:
['Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-2 Mission
Content:
Sentinel-2 is a European wide-swath, high-resolution, multi-spectral imaging mission. The full mission specification of the twin satellites flying in the same orbit but phased at 180°, is designed to give a high revisit frequency of 5 days at the Equator.
Each of the satellites in the Sentinel-2 mission carries a single payload: the optical [Multi-Spectral Instrument](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s2-mission#S2-Mission-MSI-Instrument) (MSI) that samples 13 spectral bands: four bands at 10 m, six bands at 20 m and three bands at 60 m spatial resolution. The orbital swath width is 290 km.

**Figure 1: The Twin-Satellite Sentinel-2 Orbital Configuration [Credits: Astrium GmbH]**
The Sentinel-2 twin satellites carry on the legacy of [SPOT](https://earth.esa.int/eogateway/missions/spot) and [LANDSAT](https://landsat.gsfc.nasa.gov/) by continuing to provide similar types of image data and contributing to ongoing multispectral observations. These satellites are used to support a variety of services and applications offered by [Copernicus](https://www.copernicus.eu/en), including land management, agriculture, forestry, disaster control, humanitarian relief operations, risk mapping, and security concerns.', 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Acquisition Resolutions
Content:
The resolutions of the Sentinel-2 Mission and its payload MSI instrument are:
1. The **temporal resolution** of a satellite in orbit is the revisit frequency of the satellite to a...
2. The **spatial resolution** of an instrument is the _at-ground_ representation of an individual...
3. The [**spectral resolution**](https://sentiwiki.copernicus...
4. The **radiometric resolution** of an instrument is a determination of the incremental level of...
5. The **swath width** of Sentinel-2 is 290 km. In comparison, the swath width of Landsat 5 TM and...', "Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > MSI Instrument
Content:
**Figure 9: VNIR Flight Focal Plane [Credits: Astrium SAS (France) and e2v Technologies (UK)]**
The design of the MSI on-board Sentinel-2 has been driven by the requirement for large swath high geometrical and spectral performance of the measurements.
The MSI measures the Earth's reflected radiance in 13 spectral bands from VNIR to SWIR (**Table 2**). All the details about the measured spectral responses for each band are given in the [Sentinel-2 Spectral Response Functions (S2-SRF)](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1692737/COPE-GSEG-EOPG-TN-15-0007%20-%20Sentinel-2%20Spectral%20Response%20Functions%202024%20-%204.0.xlsx?inst-v=0b38ac37-4dd6-44ba-865b-d9854aa106d8) document.
More in details, the MSI consists of the following components:
* A Three-Mirror Anastigmat (TMA) telescope with a pupil diameter equivalent to 150 mm, isostatically mounted on the platform to minimise thermo-elastic distortions. The optical design has been optimised to achieve state-of-the-art imaging quality across its very wide field of view. Its 290 km swath width is a larger swath than previous multi-spectral optical missions such as SPOT and LANDSAT. The telescope structure and the mirrors are made of silicon carbide, which provides a very high optical stability to mass ratio and minimises thermal deformation.
* Two focal planes based on:
* monolithic Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor (CMOS) detectors for VNIR
* mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detectors hybridised on a CMOS read-out circuit for SWIR (the SWIR focal plane is passively thermo-controlled at temperatures below 195 K).
* A dichroic VNIR/SWIR beam splitter. Spectral separation in the various bands is provided by stripe filters mounted on top of the detectors.
* Two distinct arrays of 12 detectors mounted on each focal plane covering VNIR and SWIR channels respectively. The 12 detectors on each focal plane are in a staggered configuration to cover the entire field of view.", 'Document: S2 Applications
Section: S2 Applications > Overview of Sentinel-2 Applications
Content:
[Sentinel-2](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel-2) is a European mission equipped with a wide-swath Multispectral Instrument (MSI) to ensure a high-revisit frequency and provide high-resolution imagery to support the Copernicus programme.
Sentinel-2 data products are made available systematically and free of charge to all users, providing data for the following priority service areas.
To start using the data visit [CDSE browser ](https://browser.dataspace.copernicus.eu/?zoom=5&lat=50.16282&lng=20.78613&themeId=DEFAULT-THEME&visualizationUrl=U2FsdGVkX1%2B4%2BV%2FOaiXMG%2FrmYxraCDY%2F...', 'Document: S2 Products
Section: S2 Products > MSI Products Overview
Content:
The continuous acquisition of Sentinel-2 image data in a given MSI mode is called a "datatake". The maximum length of an imaging datatake is 15,000 km (e.g. continuous observation from northern Russia to southern Africa). All products contain granules/tiles from a single datatake. A datatake is presented inside a product as a set of one or more datastrips (corresponding to acquisition segments downlinked to different ground stations, please see **Figure 1** below).

**Figure 1: Sentinel-2 Datatake split in three Datastrips. [Credits: Exprivia]**
The products are elementary granules of fixed size, within a single orbit. A granule is the minimum indivisible partition of a product (containing all possible spectral bands).
For Level-1B granules are small images in sensor geometry sensed by each of the twelve MSI detectors and are 23 km x 25 Km large.
For Level-1C and Level-2A, the granules, also called tiles, are 110 km x 110 km ortho-images projected onto the Universal Transversal Mercator (UTM) spatial reference system, which divides Earth into 60 longitudinal zones. Each UTM zone has a vertical width of 6° of longitude and horizontal width of 8° of latitude (see **Figure 2**). Earth is subdivided on a predefined set of tiles, defined in UTM/WGS84 projection and using a 100 km step. However, each tile has a surface of 110 km x 110 km in order to provide large overlap with the neighbouring.

**Figure 2: Level-1C product tiling**
Tiles can be fully or partially covered by image data. Partially covered tiles correspond to those at the edge or top/bottom of the Datastrip.
Download is available here: [Sentinel-2 tiling grid kml](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1692737/S2A_OPER_GIP_TILPAR_MPC__20151209T095117_V20150622T000000_21000101T000000_B00.zip?inst-v=0b38ac37-4dd6-44ba-865b-d9854aa106d8).', "Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-2 Mission > Geographical Coverage
Content:
![](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1687033/figure-6...
**Figure 6: Number of acquisitions for Sentinel-2A/B/C MSI in 20 days period**
During the [Sentinel-2A extension campaign](https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/-/sentinel-2a-extended-campaign-starting-march-13-2025), Sentinel-2A is located 36° away from Sentinel-2B, ensuring that Sentinel-2A and Sentinel-2B are acquiring neighbouring relative orbits, with a 10 min time difference, generating a 'virtual' extended swath (**Figure 7**).
![](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1687033/image-20250425-102415...
**Figure 7: The generated pseudo ‘extended’ swath acquisition (A and B with a 10 min acquisition gap)**
Please refer to the [Sentinel-2 descending orbits](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1673423/Sentinel-2%20Descending%20Orbits%20shape%20file.zip?inst-v=0b38ac37-4dd6-44ba-865b-d9854aa106d8).", 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Acquisition Resolutions > Spectral Resolution
Content:
Spectral resolution is defined as a measure of the ability of the instrument to distinguish features in the electromagnetic spectrum.
The 13 spectral bands of Sentinel-2 range from the Visible and Near Infra-Red (VNIR) to the Short-Wave Infra-Red (SWIR):
* 4 x 10 metre Bands: the three classical RGB bands (Blue (~493nm), Green (560nm), and Red (~665nm)) and a Near Infra-Red (~833nm) band;
* 6 x 20 metre Bands: 4 narrow Bands in the VNIR vegetation red edge spectral domain (~704nm,~740nm, ~783nm and ~865nm) and 2 wider SWIR bands (~1610nm and ~2190nm) for applications such as snow/ice/cloud detection, or vegetation moisture stress assessment;
* 3 x 60 metre Bands mainly focused on cloud screening and atmospheric correction (~443nm for aerosols and ~945nm for water vapour) and cirrus detection (~1374nm).  
**NOTE:** The Bandwidth (nm) in the Tables below is the values measured at Full Width Half Maximum (FWHM). The equivalent wavelength is the barycentre of the spectral response function, not considering the solar irradiance:', 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-2 Mission > Geographical Coverage
Content:
The Sentinel-2 mission will provide systematic coverage over the following areas:
* all continental land surfaces (including inland waters) between latitudes 56° South and 82.8° North
* all coastal waters up to 20 km from the shore
* all islands greater than 100 km2
* all EU islands
* the Mediterranean Sea
* all closed seas (e.g. Caspian Sea).  
In addition, the Sentinel-2 observation scenario includes observations following member states or Copernicus Services requests (e.g. Antarctica, Baffin Bay).
**Figures 4** illustrates the coverage foreseen for the baseline scenario of MSI acquisitions (two satellites in orbit).
![Revisit scenario ](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1687033/Revisit%20scenario%202025...
**Figure 4: Coverage and revisit time for the baseline scenario of Sentinel-2 MSI acquisitions.**
In addition, the [Sentinel-2 extension campaign](https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/-/sentinel-2a-extended-campaign-starting-march-13-2025) complements the nominal constellation operations, enhancing the revisit frequency over Europe and tropical regions of Africa and South America, frequently impacted by high cloud cover (**Figure 5**).
![](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1687033/figure-5...
**Figure 5: Number of revisits for Sentinel-2A/B/C MSI in 20 days period**
With nominal two-satellites (Sentinel-2B/2C) operations configuration, all regular areas, indicated in green in **Figure 4** , will be revisited every five days under the same viewing conditions (i.e. viewing angles). The [Sentinel-2A extension campaign](https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/-/sentinel-2a-extended-campaign-starting-march-13-2025) brings an improved revisit frequency for some areas. However, due to overlap between swaths from adjacent orbits, the revisit frequency is increased with different viewing conditions, as shown in **Figure 6**.
![](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1687033/figure-6...', 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-2 Mission > Satellite Description
Content:
The two Sentinel-2 satellites in the nominal configuration operate simultaneously, phased at 180° to each other, in a sun-synchronous orbit at a mean altitude of 786 km. During the extension campaign, Sentinel-2A is located 36° away from Sentinel-2B. The position of each Sentinel-2 satellite in its orbit is measured by a dual-frequency Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receiver. Orbital accuracy is maintained by a dedicated propulsion system.
The satellite lifespan is 7.25 years, which includes a 3 month in-orbit commissioning phase. Batteries and propellants have...
The Sentinel-2 satellite system was developed by an industrial consortium led by Astrium GmbH (Germany). Astrium SAS (France) is responsible for the MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI).
The [MSI](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s2-mission#S2-Mission-MSI-Instrument) works passively, by collecting sunlight reflected from the Earth. New data is acquired by the instrument as the satellite moves along its orbital path. The incoming light beam is split via a beam-splitter and focused onto two separate focal plane assemblies within the instrument; one for Visible and Near-Infra-Red (VNIR) bands and the other one for Short Wave Infra-Red (SWIR) bands. The spectral separation of each band into individual wavelengths is accomplished by stripe filters mounted on top of the detectors.', 'Document: S2 Processing
Section: S2 Processing > L1B Algorithms > Geometric processing > Viewing model refining
Content:
**Figure 5: Overview of Sentinel-2 GRI images**
Products over Svalbard, isolated islands at high latitude and Antarctica are not covered by the GRI so are not refined. Moreover, several orbits covering Greenland and Northern Canada (Nunavut and Yukon territories) could not be completed. Please also note that orbit R109 is empty because it is almost totally located over sea.
To meet the last condition ensuring a high correlation between the compared images (similar geometry), resampling the two segments in a common virtual geometry is needed, because of Sentinel-2 specificities: the images are split in 12 detectors and the pointing precision is at worst 2 kms.
This viewing model of the common virtual geometry is computed by:
* constructing an average regular datation model over the segment to refine
* selecting the attitude and orbital data of the segment to refine
* and by computing regular viewing directions, as if it were a push-broom sensor, composed of one single detector, covering the whole Sentinel-2 swath  
The two images are then resampled, using the resampling grids, an interpolation filter and the definition of interest area for each detector, as illustrated in **Figure 6.** Then the correlation is performed between two monolithic images composed of one single detector....']
response:
The provided context does not contain any information about a Sentinel-2 SAR instrument. All the details given are about the Sentinel-2 optical Multispectral Instrument (MSI), which has a swath width of 290 km.

The context states:

"Each of the satellites in the Sentinel-2 mission carries a single payload: the optical [Multi-Spectral Instrument](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s2-mission#S2-Mission-MSI-Instrument) (MSI) that samples 13 spectral bands: four bands at 10 m, six bands at 20 m and three bands at 60 m spatial resolution. The orbital swath width is 290 km."

There is no mention of a SAR instrument on Sentinel-2 in the provided documentation. The Sentinel-2 mission is equipped solely with the optical MSI payload, not a SAR instrument.

Therefore, based on the available context, I cannot provide any information about the swath width of a Sentinel-2 SAR instrument, as the Sentinel-2 satellites do not carry a SAR instrument.
reference: Sentinel-2 does not carry a SAR instrument; it is an optical mission (MSI). Sentinel-1 is the SAR mission.

user_input: Can Sentinel-1 detect vegetation health using the Red Edge band?
retrieved_contexts:
['Document: S1 Applications
Section: S1 Applications > Land Monitoring > Forestry
Content:
Sentinel-1 can play an important role in sustainable forest management with clear-cut and partial-cut detection, forest type classification, biomass estimation and disturbance detection. For climate change, mapping of forest fire scars can be an important part of mapping the carbon history of a forest and plays a critical role in the estimation of carbon emissions. Land cover maps can be used to support forest management and the monitoring of illegal timber harvesting worldwide.
For this application the most suitable product is the Interferometric Wide with dual polarisation. In fact, the cross -polarisation VH is more sensitive to change in vegetation density and structure while the polarisation ratio VH/VV is an important index for vegetation phenology or water content (European Wide Forest Classification Based on Sentinel-1 Data).

**Figure 1: Deforestation detection map over Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam from 2018 to 2020. Credits:** [EO Science for Society - ESA** _]_**', 'Document: S1 Applications
Section: S1 Applications > Land Monitoring > Agriculture
Content:
Monitoring of crop conditions, soil properties and mapping tillage activities, help to assess land use, predict harvests, monitor seasonal changes and assist in implementing policy for sustainable development. Sentinel-1 can also be used for monitoring the changes of agricultural production and productivity of pastures caused by drought and monitoring the decline of land productivity and soil degradation due to excessive cultivation and pasturage and improper irrigation.
Agricultural maps enable provision of independent and objective estimates of the extent of cultivation in a given country or growing season, which can be used to support efforts to ensure food security in vulnerable areas.
Both SLC and GRD products can be used for crop monitoring, depending on the parameter of interest. Typically, if the SAR intensity is preferred, then the GRD is the only product needed. However, if more information are necessary, polarimetric parameters are requested so SLC product should be selected.
For both product types, double polarisation shall be selected as cross-polarised VH backscatter is highly sensitive to changes in vegetation densities and structure and polarisation ratio VH/VV is sensitive to vegetation phenology or water content.

**Figure 2: Monitoring of expansion of rubber plantation with Sentinel-2 / Sentinel-1. Contains modified Copernicus data [2015-2017], processed by SIRS.**

**Figure 3: Land cover view, North East of Guyana, 2017. The image was acquired in IW mode, GRD level, VH poalrisation.[Credits:**[Mundialis | Ecosystem...

**Figure 4: Rice fields in Mekong Delta, Vietnam (2020). Multi-temporal image combining three radar acquisitions taken around one month apart to show changes in crop and land conditions over time. [Credits: ESA**[Rice fields, Vietnam](https://www.esa.int/ESA_Multimedia/Images/2020/03/Rice_fields_Vietnam)**]**', 'Document: S1 Mission
Section: S1 Mission > The Sentinel-1 mission is the European Radar Observatory for the Copernicus joint initiative of the European Commission (EC) and the European Space Agency (ESA). Copernicus is a European initiative for the implementation of information services dealing with environment and security. It is based on observation data received from Earth Observation satellites and ground-based information.
Content:
The Sentinel-1 mission comprises a constellation of two sun-synchronous polar-orbiting satellites, sharing the same orbital plane with 180° orbital phasing difference, operating day and night performing C-band synthetic aperture radar imaging, enabling them to acquire imagery regardless of the weather. It operates in four exclusive imaging modes with different resolution (down to 5 m) and coverage (up to 400 km). It provides dual polarisation capability, very short revisit times and rapid product delivery. For each observation, precise measurements of spacecraft position and attitude are available.
Sentinel-1 works in a pre-programmed operation mode to avoid conflicts and to produce a consistent long-term data archive built for applications based on long time series.
Sentinel-1 is the first of the five missions that ESA developed for the Copernicus initiative. Its measurement domain covers landscape topography, multi-purpose imagery (land), multi-purpose imagery (ocean), ocean surface winds, ocean topography/currents, ocean wave height and spectrum, sea ice cover, edge and thickness, snow cover, edge and depth, soil moisture and vegetation.
Sentinel-1 main [**Mission Objectives and Applications**](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s1-applications) are:  
**Media 1: Sentinel-1 Radar Mission [Credits: ESA]**
For mission planning information, see the [Observation and Production Scenario](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s1-mission#S1-Mission-Observation-and-Production-Scenarios).
**Launch timeline**
Sentinel-1A was launched on 3 April 2014.
Sentinel-1B was launched on 25 April 2016. The spacecraft experienced an anomaly related to the...
Sentinel-1C was launched on 5 December 2024. Sentinel-1D launch was launched on 4 November 2025.', 'Document: S1 Applications
Section: S1 Applications > Sentinel-1 delivers radar imagery for numerous applications. SAR images are the best way of tracking land subsidence and structural damage: systematic observations and enhanced interferometric capabilities make ground movement barely noticeable in everyday life detectable and closely monitorable. As well as being a valuable resource for urban planners, this kind of information is essential for monitoring shifts from earthquakes, landslides and volcanic uplift. Moreover it helps geohazard monitoring, mining, geology and city planning through subsidence risk assessment.
Content:
The mission’s dual polarimetric products benefit users interested in agriculture, forestry and land cover classification.
The SAR ability to provide observation in all weather, and in day or night time conditions, makes it ideal for maritime and Arctic monitoring. Images acquired over the ocean are essential for generating timely maps of sea ice for safe passage, for detecting and tracking oil spills and offer key information on wind and waves in the open sea for shipping and wave-energy applications.
Finally, Sentinel-1 is designed specifically to provide images for rapid response to disasters such as floods and earthquakes.
Through the products provided, security users can monitor major shipping routes to detect illegal activities, gather prosecution evidence in case of illegal discharges, detect unexpected building in remote areas, monitor deforestation and support search and rescue activities.
The mission’s main characteristics such as short revisit time and rapid data dissemination benefit emergency response users, such as the United Nations [The International Charter Space and Major Disasters](http://www.disasterscharter.org/), in emergency situations such as floods, earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and landslides.
Each application can be better served by specific acquisition modes and product types as shown in the table below. The Interferometric Wide swath mode is the primary operation mode for most applications over land. Description of each product type and format is available: [Products](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s1-products).
Refer to the [High-Level Operation Plan](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1673407/COPE-S1OP-EOPG-PL-15-0020%20-%20Sentinel%20HLOP%202021%20-%203.1.pdf?inst-v=0b38ac37-4dd6-44ba-865b-d9854aa106d8) (HLOP) for a description of the acquisition...
_Table 1: Mapping of most common mode and application type used based on the processing baseline_
**Applications** | **Acquisition Mode** | **Product Type**
---|---|---', "Document: S1 Applications
Section: S1 Applications > Emergency Management > Flood Monitoring
Content:
Over 75% of natural disasters that occur worldwide involve flooding. SAR's inherent capability to observe during cloud cover and Sentinel-1's frequent revisits makes it ideal for flood monitoring. It can be used to assess the extent of flooded areas and the impact on human, economic and environmental loss. Furthermore, high-resolution digital elevation models (DEMs) generated through Sentinel-1's interferometric modes can be used to conduct run-off and inundation analysis in areas previously lacking elevation data.
Calm open water surfaces appear flat when being hit by C-band SAR radiation, and the radiation is scattered away from the satellite’s sensor. Consequently, the received energy (measured as backscatter) is low and shows high contrast to general land surfaces. Generally, the underlying principle of the SAR-based flood mapping methods is to identify low backscatter measurements where land is expected under normal conditions. Two SAR polarisations (VV and VH) are required to allow a detection of flooded vegetation.

**Figure 20: Mapping of flooded areas in Bangladesh in 2016 from semi-automatic classification of Sentinel-1 data. Map generated as part of the**[Copernicus Emergency Management Service](http://emergency.copernicus.eu/) **[Credits: EMS/SIRS]**

**Figure 21: Data captured from space on 30 August 2022 was used to map the extent of flooding propagating in Pakistan from August 10 to September 23, 2022. Credits: ESA**[Pakistan inundated**]**

**Figure 22: Animation of flood devastating Bangladesh acquired on 4 May, 16 May, 28 May, 9 June and 21 June 2022. Ref: ESA**[Copernicus Sentinel-1 maps Bangladesh flood**]**", 'Document: S1 Applications
Section: S1 Applications > Sentinel-1 delivers radar imagery for numerous applications. SAR images are the best way of tracking land subsidence and structural damage: systematic observations and enhanced interferometric capabilities make ground movement barely noticeable in everyday life detectable and closely monitorable. As well as being a valuable resource for urban planners, this kind of information is essential for monitoring shifts from earthquakes, landslides and volcanic uplift. Moreover it helps geohazard monitoring, mining, geology and city planning through subsidence risk assessment.

**Forestry** |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️ |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️ |  |  |  |  |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️ |

**Urban deformation mapping** |  | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️ |
**Flood monitoring** | ✔️ |  |  |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ |  |  |  |  |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️ |

**Landslide and volcano monitoring** |  | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ |  | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ |  |  |  |  |  |  | ✔️ |  |
_Note: for a number of small volcanic islands worldwide, from May 2015 onwards, the Stripmap mode (SM) is used for the regular coverage. This is implemented in the case a SM swath fully covers the island in one pass, and no maritime surveillance activities take place around the island. The SM mode features (at a comparable system resource consumption) a smaller swath w.r.t the IW mode (in the order of 80 km vs 250 km) but ensures a higher spatial resolution, of particular interest for volcano monitoring._', 'Document: S1 Applications

Content:
To start using the data visit [CDSE browser ](https://browser.dataspace.copernicus.eu/?zoom=5&lat=50.16282&lng=20.78613&themeId=DEFAULT-THEME&visualizationUrl=U2FsdGVkX18q4LSvU%2Fo1%2FQ3Ki07yzwkfXSn2SQ...
The user is addressed to the page [Sentinels Toolboxes](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/sentinels-toolboxes#Sentinel-1-Toolbox) to verify the available processing tools for the Sentinel 1 mission.', "Document: S1 Mission
Section: S1 Mission > SAR Instrument > Geophysical Measurements
Content:
Copernicus Sentinel-1's C-band SAR active sensor can observe the Earth's surface at any time of the day or night, regardless of weather and environmental conditions. SAR has the advantage of operating at wavelengths not impeded by cloud cover or lack of illumination.
Unlike passive optical sensors that require the sun's illumination, an active SAR instrument transmits its own microwave signal to illuminate the Earth's surface at an angle. SAR actively transmits microwave signals towards the Earth and receives a portion of transmitted energy as backscatter from the ground. The returned backscatter echo of the scene is received by the instrument's antenna a short time later at a slightly different location, as the satellite travels along its orbit. The brightness amplitude of the returned signal, along with its phase information, is recorded to construct an image of the scene.
The SAR instrument provides radar backscatter measurements influenced by the terrain structure and surface roughness. Generally, the more roughness or structure on the ground, the greater the backscatter. Rough surfaces will scatter the energy and return a significant amount back to the antenna resulting in a bright feature. Flat surfaces reflect the signal away resulting in a dark feature. Likewise, more structurally complex targets such as forests will appear brighter as signal interaction with the leaves, branches and trunks will result in a higher proportion of the signal being transmitted back to the sensor.
The dielectric constant of the materials on the ground also play a factor in the measurements. In the microwave region of the spectrum, most natural materials have a dielectric constant in the range of 3 to 8 when dry, whereas water has a dielectric constant of approximately 80. The dielectric constant indicates the reflectivity and conductivity of materials. Therefore, the...", 'Document: S1 Mission
Section: S1 Mission > SAR Instrument > Polarimetry
Content:
Copernicus Sentinel-1 can collect several different images from the same series of pulses by using its antenna to receive specific polarisations simultaneously. Copernicus Sentinel-1 is a phase-preserving dual polarisation SAR system. It can transmit a signal in either horizontal (H) or vertical (V) polarisation, and then receive in both H and V polarisations. Dual polarisation Level-1 Single Look Complex (SLC) products contain complex values. In addition to the backscatter intensity that can be measured from each single polarisation, the inter-channel phase information allows to perform enhanced analysis of backscattering properties.
Targets on the ground have distinctive polarisation signatures reflecting different polarisations with different intensities and converting one polarisation into another. For example, volume scatterers (e.g. forest canopy) have different polarisation properties than surface scatterers (e.g. sea surface). Polarimetric techniques such as polarimetric target decomposition (eigenvector-based, model-based, ...) allow the separation of different scattering contributions and can be used to extract information about the scattering process. Dedicated dual-Pol SAR classification techniques allow improved classification of point targets and distributed target areas.
The following RADARSAT-2 image of Flevoland in the Netherlands shows the difference in intensities from VH (left) and VV (centre). The composite RGB (colour) image on the right was created using the VV channel for red, VH channel for green and the ratio |VV| / |VH| for blue.

**Figure 8: Intensities from different polarimetric channels [Credits: MDA and CSA]**', 'Document: S1 Products
Section: S1 Products > Related Production > **Sentinel-1 Global Backscatter Model (S1GBM)**
Content:
**Figure 15: Mapping Earth's land surface with C-band Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR)**
**Description**
The Sentinel-1 Global Backscatter Model (S1GBM) describes the C-band radar cross section of the Earth's land surface for the period between 2016 and 2017, generated from 460,000 Copernicus Sentinel-1 IW GRDH (Ground-Range Detected High Resolution) backscatter measurements normalised to the reference incidence angle of 38°. This release of the S1GBM comprises two global mosaics describing the temporal mean of sigma nought backscatter s0(38, t) in VV- and VH-polarisation respectively.
The S1GBM supports the testing, design, and verification of upcoming radar sensors, related SAR-processor performance simulations, raw data compression optimisation, and visualisation purposes. It also presents a valuable environmental record for investigating the C-band VV/VH backscatter response over different land covers, and documenting the state of the land surface in 2016 and 2017.
**Data Set Specifications**
The S1GBM VV and VH mosaics are georeferenced to the Equi7Grid and divided into six continental zones (Africa, Asia, Europe, North America, Oceania, South America), which are further divided into square tiles of 100 km extent ("T1"-tiles). The dataset is organised in 12 collections, one for each of the 6 continents and the 2 polarisations. In addition to the original data images, downsampled quicklook-files of same geographic extent are available for all tiles, allowing for a convenient preview of the data. With this setup, the S1GBM consists of 16,071 tiles over 6 continents, for VV and VH each, totalling to a data volume of 2.67 TB.
The tiles' file-format is a LZW-compressed GeoTIFF holding 16-bit integer values, with tagged metadata on encoding and georeference. Compatibility with common geographic information systems, such as QGIS or ArcGIS, and geodata libraries, such as GDAL, is given.']
response:
Based on the information provided in the context, Sentinel-1 does not have the capability to detect vegetation health using a Red Edge band.

The key points are:

1. Sentinel-1 is a Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) mission that operates in the C-band microwave spectrum. It does not have any optical/multispectral imaging capabilities.

2. The documentation does not mention Sentinel-1 having a Red Edge band, which is a key spectral band used for monitoring vegetation health and chlorophyll content. Red Edge bands are typically found on optical/multispectral sensors like Sentinel-2.

3. The applications of Sentinel-1 discussed in the context focus on using SAR backscatter and polarimetric information for applications like forestry, agriculture, and land cover classification. There is no indication that Sentinel-1 can directly measure vegetation health parameters like the Red Edge.

4. The context states that the cross-polarization VH backscatter and the VH/VV polarization ratio are more sensitive to vegetation structure and water content, but these are not the same as a dedicated Red Edge band.

In summary, Sentinel-1 does not have the capability to detect vegetation health using a Red Edge band, as it is a SAR mission without any optical/multispectral imaging sensors. The vegetation-related applications of Sentinel-1 rely on the analysis of SAR backscatter and polarimetric properties, rather than spectral information from Red Edge or other optical bands.
reference: No. Sentinel-1 is a Radar (SAR) satellite. Vegetation health via Red Edge bands is monitored by the Optical satellite Sentinel-2.

user_input: Does Sentinel-2 carry a Thermal Infrared (TIR) sensor?
retrieved_contexts:
["Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > MSI Instrument
Content:
**Figure 9: VNIR Flight Focal Plane [Credits: Astrium SAS (France) and e2v Technologies (UK)]**
The design of the MSI on-board Sentinel-2 has been driven by the requirement for large swath high geometrical and spectral performance of the measurements.
The MSI measures the Earth's reflected radiance in 13 spectral bands from VNIR to SWIR (**Table 2**). All the details about the measured spectral responses for each band are given in the [Sentinel-2 Spectral Response Functions (S2-SRF)](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1692737/COPE-GSEG-EOPG-TN-15-0007%20-%20Sentinel-2%20Spectral%20Response%20Functions%202024%20-%204.0.xlsx?inst-v=0b38ac37-4dd6-44ba-865b-d9854aa106d8) document.
More in details, the MSI consists of the following components:
* A Three-Mirror Anastigmat (TMA) telescope with a pupil diameter equivalent to 150 mm, isostatically mounted on the platform to minimise thermo-elastic distortions. The optical design has been optimised to achieve state-of-the-art imaging quality across its very wide field of view. Its 290 km swath width is a larger swath than previous multi-spectral optical missions such as SPOT and LANDSAT. The telescope structure and the mirrors are made of silicon carbide, which provides a very high optical stability to mass ratio and minimises thermal deformation.
* Two focal planes based on:
* monolithic Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor (CMOS) detectors for VNIR
* mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detectors hybridised on a CMOS read-out circuit for SWIR (the SWIR focal plane is passively thermo-controlled at temperatures below 195 K).
* A dichroic VNIR/SWIR beam splitter. Spectral separation in the various bands is provided by stripe filters mounted on top of the detectors.
* Two distinct arrays of 12 detectors mounted on each focal plane covering VNIR and SWIR channels respectively. The 12 detectors on each focal plane are in a staggered configuration to cover the entire field of view.", 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-2 Mission
Content:
Sentinel-2 is a European wide-swath, high-resolution, multi-spectral imaging mission. The full mission specification of the twin satellites flying in the same orbit but phased at 180°, is designed to give a high revisit frequency of 5 days at the Equator.
Each of the satellites in the Sentinel-2 mission carries a single payload: the optical [Multi-Spectral Instrument](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s2-mission#S2-Mission-MSI-Instrument) (MSI) that samples 13 spectral bands: four bands at 10 m, six bands at 20 m and three bands at 60 m spatial resolution. The orbital swath width is 290 km.

**Figure 1: The Twin-Satellite Sentinel-2 Orbital Configuration [Credits: Astrium GmbH]**
The Sentinel-2 twin satellites carry on the legacy of [SPOT](https://earth.esa.int/eogateway/missions/spot) and [LANDSAT](https://landsat.gsfc.nasa.gov/) by continuing to provide similar types of image data and contributing to ongoing multispectral observations. These satellites are used to support a variety of services and applications offered by [Copernicus](https://www.copernicus.eu/en), including land management, agriculture, forestry, disaster control, humanitarian relief operations, risk mapping, and security concerns.', 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-2 Mission > Satellite Description
Content:
The two Sentinel-2 satellites in the nominal configuration operate simultaneously, phased at 180° to each other, in a sun-synchronous orbit at a mean altitude of 786 km. During the extension campaign, Sentinel-2A is located 36° away from Sentinel-2B. The position of each Sentinel-2 satellite in its orbit is measured by a dual-frequency Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receiver. Orbital accuracy is maintained by a dedicated propulsion system.
The satellite lifespan is 7.25 years, which includes a 3 month in-orbit commissioning phase. Batteries and propellants have...
The Sentinel-2 satellite system was developed by an industrial consortium led by Astrium GmbH (Germany). Astrium SAS (France) is responsible for the MultiSpectral Instrument (MSI).
The [MSI](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s2-mission#S2-Mission-MSI-Instrument) works passively, by collecting sunlight reflected from the Earth. New data is acquired by the instrument as the satellite moves along its orbital path. The incoming light beam is split via a beam-splitter and focused onto two separate focal plane assemblies within the instrument; one for Visible and Near-Infra-Red (VNIR) bands and the other one for Short Wave Infra-Red (SWIR) bands. The spectral separation of each band into individual wavelengths is accomplished by stripe filters mounted on top of the detectors.', 'Document: S2 Applications
Section: S2 Applications > Overview of Sentinel-2 Applications > Sentinel-2 band combinations for specific applications
Content:
* **False Colour (urban):** This composite is used to visualise urbanized areas more clearly. Vegetation is visible in shades of green, while urbanised areas are represented by white, grey, or purple. Soils, sand, and minerals are shown in a variety of colours. Snow and ice appear as dark blue, and water as black or blue. Flooded areas are very dark blue and almost black. The composite is useful for detecting wildfires and calderas of volcanoes, as they are displayed in shades of red and yellow.
* **Moisture Index:** The Normalised Difference Moisture Index (NDMI) is used to determine vegetation water content and monitor droughts
* **SWIR:** Short Wave Infrared (SWIR) measurements can help scientists estimate how much water is present in plants and soil, as water absorbs SWIR wavelengths
* **NDWI:** The Normalised Difference Water Index (NDWI) is most appropriate for water body mapping
* **NDSI:** The Sentinel-2 Normalised Difference Snow Index (NDSI) can be used to differentiate between cloud and snow cover as snow absorbs in the short-wave infrared light, but reflects the visible light, whereas cloud is generally reflective in both wavelengths. Snow cover is represented in bright vivid blue.
* **Scene classification:** Scene classification was developed to distinguish between cloudy pixels, clear pixels and water pixels of Sentinel-2 data and is a result of ESA’s Scene classification algorithm for Level-2A products only.', 'Document: S2 Applications
Section: S2 Applications > Overview of Sentinel-2 Applications
Content:
[Sentinel-2](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel-2) is a European mission equipped with a wide-swath Multispectral Instrument (MSI) to ensure a high-revisit frequency and provide high-resolution imagery to support the Copernicus programme.
Sentinel-2 data products are made available systematically and free of charge to all users, providing data for the following priority service areas.
To start using the data visit [CDSE browser ](https://browser.dataspace.copernicus.eu/?zoom=5&lat=50.16282&lng=20.78613&themeId=DEFAULT-THEME&visualizationUrl=U2FsdGVkX1%2B4%2BV%2FOaiXMG%2FrmYxraCDY%2F...', 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Acquisition Resolutions > Spectral Resolution
Content:
Spectral resolution is defined as a measure of the ability of the instrument to distinguish features in the electromagnetic spectrum.
The 13 spectral bands of Sentinel-2 range from the Visible and Near Infra-Red (VNIR) to the Short-Wave Infra-Red (SWIR):
* 4 x 10 metre Bands: the three classical RGB bands (Blue (~493nm), Green (560nm), and Red (~665nm)) and a Near Infra-Red (~833nm) band;
* 6 x 20 metre Bands: 4 narrow Bands in the VNIR vegetation red edge spectral domain (~704nm,~740nm, ~783nm and ~865nm) and 2 wider SWIR bands (~1610nm and ~2190nm) for applications such as snow/ice/cloud detection, or vegetation moisture stress assessment;
* 3 x 60 metre Bands mainly focused on cloud screening and atmospheric correction (~443nm for aerosols and ~945nm for water vapour) and cirrus detection (~1374nm).  
**NOTE:** The Bandwidth (nm) in the Tables below is the values measured at Full Width Half Maximum (FWHM). The equivalent wavelength is the barycentre of the spectral response function, not considering the solar irradiance:', 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Performance
Content:
Sentinel-2 products respect stringent radiometric and geometric image quality requirements. For further information, please refer to the [monthly data quality and annual performance reports](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/document-library#Library-S2-Performance-DQR) (including the [Sentinel-2 Annual Performance Report – Year 2024](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1673423/OMPC.CS.APR.005%20-%20S2%20MSI%20Annual%20Performance%20Report%202024%20-%201.1.pdf?inst-v=0b38ac37-4dd6-44ba-865b-d9854aa106d8)).', 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-2 Mission > Satellite Description
Content:
**Figure 2: Schematic View of the Deployed Sentinel-2 Spacecraft [Credits: EADS Astrium]**
The optical design of the MSI telescope allows for a 290 km Field Of View (FOV).
A shutter mechanism prevents the instrument from direct illumination by the sun in orbit and to avoid contamination during launch. The same mechanism functions as a calibration device by collecting the sunlight after reflection by a diffuser.', 'Document: S2 Applications
Section: S2 Applications > Overview of Sentinel-2 Applications > Sentinel-2 band combinations for specific applications
Content:
The table below reports the most common band combinations of Sentinel-2 products, which are used based on the different applications discussed above. Other possible bands combinations can be used in specific study cases. More information about the spectral characteristics and resolution of the Sentinel-2 Multispectral Instrument (MSI) is available on the [S2 Mission webpage](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s2-mission).
**Table 1: Sentinel-2 band combinations**
**Application** |  **Layers** **Band combination** | **Product type**
---|---|---
**True Colour** **(B4, B3, B2)** |  **False colour** (B8, B4, B3) |  **NDVI** (B8-B4) / (B8+B4) |  **False colour (urban)** (B12, B11, B4) |  **Moisture index** (B8A-B11) / (B8A+B11) |  **SWIR** (B12, B8A, B4) |  **NDWI** (B3-B8) / (B3+B8) |  **NDSI** (B3-B11) / (B3+B11) | **Scene classification (L2A only)** | **L1C** | **L2A**
Geophysical  |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ |  | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️
Land Monitoring  | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ |  |  |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️
Maritime Monitoring | ✔️ |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️ |  | ✔️ |  |  | ✔️ | ✔️
Emergency Management  | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ |  | ✔️ |  | ✔️ | ✔️
Security - SESA | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ | ✔️ |  | ✔️ | ✔️ |  | ✔️ | ✔️
* **True colour:** Product with natural colours that represents Earth as humans would naturally see it
* **False colour:** The false colour composite is most commonly used to assess plant density and health, since plants reflect near infrared and green light, while they absorb red. Cities and exposed ground are grey or tan, and water appears blue or black.
* **NDVI:** The Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is a simple, but effective index for quantifying green vegetation. It is a measure of the state of vegetation health based on how plants reflect light at certain wavelengths.', 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Calibration and Validation Activities > Data products quality reports
Content:
The Sentinel-2 OPT-MPC provides a monthly status of the quality of Sentinel-2 L1C and L2A products via respective Data Quality Reports (DQR). The DQRs provides information on the monitoring and measurement of L1C and L2A product performances against the proposed specification.
Please note that documents providing a summary of the annual end-to-end mission performance of Sentinel-2 are available [here ](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/document-library#Library-S2-Performance-DQR)(including the report for the year 2024: [Sentinel-2 Annual Performance Report – Year 2024](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1673423/OMPC.CS.APR.005%20-%20S2%20MSI%20Annual%20Performance%20Report%202024%20-%201.1.pdf?inst-v=0b38ac37-4dd6-44ba-865b-d9854aa106d8))']
response:
Based on the information provided in the Sentinel-2 documentation, Sentinel-2 does not carry a Thermal Infrared (TIR) sensor.

The key evidence from the context is:

1. The Sentinel-2 Multispectral Instrument (MSI) is described as measuring the Earth's reflected radiance in 13 spectral bands from the Visible and Near Infrared (VNIR) to the Short-Wave Infrared (SWIR) wavelength regions. There is no mention of any Thermal Infrared bands.

2. The spectral band information provided in Document 6 lists the 13 Sentinel-2 MSI bands, which range from 443 nm to 2190 nm. This does not include any thermal infrared bands, which would typically be in the 8-14 μm wavelength region.

3. The applications and band combinations discussed in Document 9 also do not reference any Thermal Infrared bands or products from Sentinel-2.

Therefore, the context clearly indicates that the Sentinel-2 MSI instrument does not have Thermal Infrared imaging capabilities. For applications requiring Thermal Infrared data, users should refer to other Copernicus missions, such as Sentinel-3 SLSTR, which does carry a Thermal Infrared sensor.
reference: No, Sentinel-2 does not carry a thermal infrared sensor. Land Surface Temperature monitoring is covered by Sentinel-3 and the future LSTM mission.

user_input: Is the Sentinel-1B satellite currently operational?
retrieved_contexts:
['Document: S1 Mission
Section: S1 Mission > The Sentinel-1 mission is the European Radar Observatory for the Copernicus joint initiative of the European Commission (EC) and the European Space Agency (ESA). Copernicus is a European initiative for the implementation of information services dealing with environment and security. It is based on observation data received from Earth Observation satellites and ground-based information. > Orbit
Content:
Sentinel-1 is in a near-polar, sun-synchronous orbit with a 12 day repeat cycle and 175 orbits per cycle for a single satellite. Both Sentinel-1A and Sentinel-1B share the same orbit plane with a 180° orbital phasing difference. With both satellites operating, the repeat cycle is six days.

**Figure 2: Sentinel-1 Constellation [Credits: ESA/ATG medialab]**
In particular for interferometry, Sentinel-1 requires stringent orbit control. Satellite positioning along the orbit must be accurate, with pointing and timing/synchronisation between interferometric pairs. Orbit positioning control for Sentinel-1 is defined using an orbital Earth fixed "tube", 60 m (RMS) wide in radius, around a nominal operational path. The satellite is kept inside this "tube" for most of its operational lifetime.

**Figure 3: Sentinel-1 Orbit Tube [Credits: credit: ESA, TAS]**
The following table contains a summary of useful orbital information for Sentinel-1A and –1B.
_Table 1: Orbital information for Sentinel-1A and –1B:_
**Altitude** | **Inclination** | **Period** | **Cycle** | **Ref. tube deviation** | **Local Time at Ascending Node**
---|---|---|---|---|---
693 km | 98.18° | 98.6 minutes | 12 days | +- 120 m | 18:00 hours', 'Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-2 Mission > Satellite Description
Content:
The Sentinel-2 mission baseline consists of two identical satellites operating together, today Sentinel-2B (launched in 2017) and Sentinel-2C (launched in 2024) that were launched using the European VEGA launcher. Each of these satellites weighs approximately 1.2 tonnes.
As Sentinel-2A (launched in 2015) nears the end of its operational life after a decade, the launch of Sentinel-2C was critical for continuing the Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission. Sentinel-2C was launched on September 5th, 2024, and joined the other two satellites, starting to operate alongside Sentinel-2A to ensure seamless calibration and uninterrupted data collection.
Sentinel-2C has replaced Sentinel-2A in operation on January 21st, 2025, as announced [here](https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/-/precise-timing-of-transfer-of-duty-from-sentinel-2a-to-sentinel-2c-on-21-january), and Sentinel-2D will succeed Sentinel-2B. The mission will continue evolving with Sentinel-2 Next Generation, promising enhanced global measurements and continuity beyond 2035, securing essential Earth observation services.
Starting in March 2025, Sentinel-2A is performing an [extension campaign](https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/-/sentinel-2a-extended-campaign-starting-march-13-2025), exceptionally complementing the nominal two-satellites (Sentinel-2B/2C) mission constellation operations configuration. The campaign foresees the implementation of a tailored Sentinel-2A [operations scenario](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s2-mission#S2-Mission-Observation-Scenario).', 'Document: S1 Mission
Section: S1 Mission > Observation and Production Scenarios > SAR Observation Scenario
Content:
As a general principle, the polarisation scheme uses the following logic:
* HH-HV or HH polarization for the monitoring of polar environments, sea-ice zones
* VV-VH or VV polarization for all other observation zones (with an exception for the Baltic Sea observed partially in HH-HV with Sentinel-1B during northern winter)  
Please see the [Sentinel High Level Operations Plan (HLOP) ](https://omcs.atlassian.net/wiki/download/attachments/283246733/COPE-S1OP-EOPG-PL-15-0020%20-%20Sentinel%20HLOP%202021%20-%203.1.pdf?api=v2)document providing the top-level operations plan of the Sentinel missions, including...
Detailed information on the planned Sentinel-1 observations in terms of Sentinel-1 acquisitions (SAR mode, date, start-stop times, polarization, etc.) are provided with KML files available [here](https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/copernicus/sentinel-1/acquisition-plans).
**Sentinel-1C was successfully launched on December 2024 and, it is fully operational since early May 2025 (end of the commissioning phase). Sentinel-1C allowed to re-establish the 2-satellite constellation configuration: Sentinel-1A and Sentinel-1C.**
**The two maps below show an overview of the current observation plan in terms SAR mode, polarisation, observation geometry, revisit and coverage frequency. The Wave mode, continuously operated by default over open oceans, is not shown on these maps.**
![Sentinel-1-Repeat-Coverage-Frequency-Geometry-2025_1.](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1672913/Sentinel-1-Repeat-Coverage-Frequency-Ge...
**Figure 18: Sentinel-1A Mission Observation Scenario: Repeat & Coverage Frequency**
![Sentinel-1-Mode-Polarisation-Observation-Geometry-2025_1.](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1672913/Sentinel-1-Mode-Polarisation-Observatio...
**Figure 19: Sentinel-1A Mission Observation Scenario: Mode - Polarisation- Geometry**', 'Document: S1 Mission
Section: S1 Mission > Observation and Production Scenarios > SAR Observation Scenario
Content:
**Figure 19: Sentinel-1A Mission Observation Scenario: Mode - Polarisation- Geometry**
**Following an anomaly to the instrument electronics power supply on December 2021, the Sentinel-1B satellite was unable to deliver radar data.**
**The end of mission was declared in July 2022 while disposal activities have been completed on September 2024. During the time frame September 2022 – April 2025, the Sentinel-1A observation scenario was...
Please see maps below.
![](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/__attachments/1672913/Sentinel-1-Repeat-Coverage-Frequency-Geom...

**The Sentinel-1 ground segment operations implement a baseline pre-defined mission production scenario.**
This scenario foresees the systematic processing and online dissemination of all Sentinel-1 data acquired in **IW, EW and SM modes into Level-0 and Level-1 GRD products**.
GRD products are generated in High Resolution (HR) and Medium Resolution (MR).
The resolution is dependent upon the amount of multi-looking performed. Level-1 GRD products are available in HR for IW and SM modes and in MR for EW mode.
This is complemented by the systematic processing and online dissemination of:
* _Level-1 SLC products for all acquired Wave Mode data (active since October 2016 for Sentinel-1B and since May 2017 for Sentinel-1A)_', 'Document: S1 Mission
Section: S1 Mission > The Sentinel-1 mission is the European Radar Observatory for the Copernicus joint initiative of the European Commission (EC) and the European Space Agency (ESA). Copernicus is a European initiative for the implementation of information services dealing with environment and security. It is based on observation data received from Earth Observation satellites and ground-based information.
Content:
The Sentinel-1 mission comprises a constellation of two sun-synchronous polar-orbiting satellites, sharing the same orbital plane with 180° orbital phasing difference, operating day and night performing C-band synthetic aperture radar imaging, enabling them to acquire imagery regardless of the weather. It operates in four exclusive imaging modes with different resolution (down to 5 m) and coverage (up to 400 km). It provides dual polarisation capability, very short revisit times and rapid product delivery. For each observation, precise measurements of spacecraft position and attitude are available.
Sentinel-1 works in a pre-programmed operation mode to avoid conflicts and to produce a consistent long-term data archive built for applications based on long time series.
Sentinel-1 is the first of the five missions that ESA developed for the Copernicus initiative. Its measurement domain covers landscape topography, multi-purpose imagery (land), multi-purpose imagery (ocean), ocean surface winds, ocean topography/currents, ocean wave height and spectrum, sea ice cover, edge and thickness, snow cover, edge and depth, soil moisture and vegetation.
Sentinel-1 main [**Mission Objectives and Applications**](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s1-applications) are:  
**Media 1: Sentinel-1 Radar Mission [Credits: ESA]**
For mission planning information, see the [Observation and Production Scenario](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s1-mission#S1-Mission-Observation-and-Production-Scenarios).
**Launch timeline**
Sentinel-1A was launched on 3 April 2014.
Sentinel-1B was launched on 25 April 2016. The spacecraft experienced an anomaly related to the...
Sentinel-1C was launched on 5 December 2024. Sentinel-1D launch was launched on 4 November 2025.', 'Document: S3 Mission
Section: S3 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-3 Mission > Satellite Description
Content:
Sentinel-3 is a low Earth-orbit moderate size satellite compatible with small launchers including VEGA and ROCKOT. Sentinel-3 is designed for a 7 year operational lifetime with 120 kg of hydrazine propellant allowing up to 12 years of continuous operations, including de-orbiting at the end of mission. The satellite layout is driven by the need to provide a large face viewing cold-space for thermal control, a modular design for payload accommodation and simplified management of all on-board interfaces. The satellite mechanical configuration and its flight attitude have been optimised through intensive mission analysis studies and system trade-offs performed during the mission definition, resulting in significant improvements in comparison to ENVISAT.
The main subsystems of the satellite are:
* Electrical Power System (EPS), comprising one solar array wing providing power to the spacecraft and payload.
* Attitude and Orbit Control System (AOCS) composed of a coarse sun sensor, magnetometers, coarse rate sensors, star trackers, a GNSS receiver and control actuators including thrusters, magneto-torquers and reaction wheels.
* Satellite management unit for satellite commanding and monitoring.
* Data handling and mass memory unit for payload data handling.
* Mass memory units for the satellite and its payload.
* Satellite telecommunication subsystems including an S-band subsystem for both telecommand (TC) uplink and telemetry (TM) downlink, and a dedicated high volume X-band subsystem for mission data downlink.  
The main satellite platform characteristics are:
* Gyroless, three-axis stabilised platform with three star tracker heads, four reaction wheels and magnetic off-loading.
* Geodetic pointing and yaw steering.
* Eight 1 N hydrazine thrusters for in-plane and out-plane manoeuvres.
* Real-time on-board orbit accuracy determination of 3 m based on GPS and Kalman filtering.
* Launch Mass: 1 250 kg (with maturity and system margins, and fuel).', 'Document: S1 Mission
Section: S1 Mission > The Sentinel-1 mission is the European Radar Observatory for the Copernicus joint initiative of the European Commission (EC) and the European Space Agency (ESA). Copernicus is a European initiative for the implementation of information services dealing with environment and security. It is based on observation data received from Earth Observation satellites and ground-based information. > Geographical Coverage
Content:
The Copernicus Sentinel-1 constellation offers an improvement in revisit time over ERS-1/2 and Envisat ASAR, and a continuity of wide area coverage with Envisat ASAR, but achieving higher resolution and potentially global dual polarisation coverage over landmasses.
A single Sentinel-1 satellite is potentially able to map the entire world in the Interferometric Wide swath mode once every 12 days, with 175 orbits per cycle. The two-satellite constellation offers a 6 day exact repeat cycle.

**Figure 4: Sentinel-1 IW potential world coverage.**
**Note that this not reflect the operational baseline**
Since the orbit track spacing varies with latitude, the revisit rate (ascending/descending) is significantly greater at higher latitudes than at the equator: less than 1 day at the Arctic and provides coverage over Europe and Canada, main shipping routes in 1-3 days and in 3 days at the equator. Radar data are delivered to Copernicus services within an hour of acquisition.

**Figure 5: Revisit time for S-1A and S-1B in Days per Revisit**', 'Document: Copernicus Programme
Section: Copernicus Programme > **Europe’s eyes on Earth: the EU’s Copernicus Programme**
Content:
**Figure 1: Earth observation missions developed by ESA. [Credits: ESA]**
To meet the operational needs of the Copernicus programme, ESA developed the family of Sentinel satellites.
These missions are underpinned by ESA’s Earth Observation Framework - Copernicus Space Component (EOF-CSC), which oversees satellite operations, as well as data acquisition, production and dissemination. At present, three complete two-satellite constellations are in orbit, along with one additional single satellite —Sentinel-5P.
The Sentinels provide a unique set of observations, starting with the all-weather, day and night radar images from the Sentinel-1 mission, launched in 2014, 2016, 2024, and 2025 respectively.
Sentinel-2, launched in 2015, 2017, and 2024 respectively, is designed to deliver high-resolution optical images for land services.
The two Sentinel-3 satellites, launched on 16 February 2016 and 25 April 2018, provide data for services relevant to the ocean and land. Sentinel-3 marine is operated by EUMETSAT and Sentinel-3 land operated by ESA.
In addition, a Sentinel-5 Precursor mission (also known as Sentinel-5P) was developed to reduce data gaps between Envisat, in particular the SCIAMACHY instrument, and the launch of Sentinel-5.
Launched on 13 October 2017, Sentinel-5P is the first Copernicus mission in orbit dedicated to...
The Space Component is managed by ESA and serves users with satellite data available through the Sentinels and the Copernicus Contributing Missions at national, European and international levels.
The Copernicus Operations, facilitating access to Sentinel and Contributing Mission data, completes the Copernicus Space Component. [Copernicus Operations](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/copernicus-operations)
The Space Component forms the European contribution to the worldwide Global Earth Observation System of Systems (GEOSS).', 'Document: S1 Mission
Section: S1 Mission > The Sentinel-1 mission is the European Radar Observatory for the Copernicus joint initiative of the European Commission (EC) and the European Space Agency (ESA). Copernicus is a European initiative for the implementation of information services dealing with environment and security. It is based on observation data received from Earth Observation satellites and ground-based information. > Satellite Description
Content:
The satellite has been created by an industrial consortium led by Thales Alenia Space Italy as prime contractor, with Astrium Germany being responsible for the CSAR payload, incorporating the central radar electronics sub-system developed by Astrium UK.

**Figure 1: Schematic View of the Deployed Sentinel-1 Spacecraft. [Credits: TAS-I]**
The spacecraft is a three-axis, stabilised satellite, yaw/pitch/roll steering (zero Doppler), characterised by sun, star, gyro and magnetic field sensors, a set of four reaction wheels dedicated to orbit and attitude control and three torque rods as actuators to provide steering capabilities on each axis. The satellite is equipped with two solar array wings capable of producing 5 900 W (at end of life) to be stored in a modular battery, the battery capacity is 324 Ah.
The satellite is based on the PRIMA (Piattaforma Italiana Multi Applicativa) bus, building on the experience gained from RADARSAT-2 and COSMO-SkyMed, which use the same bus. The bus provides highly accurate pointing knowledge (better than 0.004°) on each axis, high attitude accuracy (about 0.01° on each axis) and real-time orbit...
The reference orbit will be maintained within an Earth-fixed orbital tube of a diameter of 120 m (RMS) during normal operation.
The satellite platform provides features for the management of the attitude and orbit control systems, science data handling with storage capability of 1,410 Gb, propulsion, power, thermal control, spacecraft autonomy and failure detection identification and recovery, and communication with the ground via X-band data downlink and optical data link through EDRS for payload data at 520 Mbit/s; S-band 64 kbps uplink and 128 kbps / 2 Mbps downlink for TM/TC.
The total mass of the spacecraft at launch is approximately 2 300 kg (including 130 kg fuel).', 'Document: SentiWiki
Section: SentiWiki > Sentinel-1
Content:
The Sentinel-1 mission comprises a constellation of two polar-orbiting satellites, operating day and night performing C-band synthetic aperture

response:
Based on the information provided in the context, the Sentinel-1B satellite is no longer operational:

**Sentinel-1B Operational Status**
- According to Document 4, following an anomaly to the instrument electronics power supply on December 2021, the Sentinel-1B satellite was unable to deliver radar data.
- The end of mission for Sentinel-1B was declared in July 2022, and the disposal activities were completed in September 2024.

**Sentinel-1 Constellation Configuration**
- During the time frame from September 2022 to April 2025, the Sentinel-1 observation scenario was based solely on the Sentinel-1A satellite.
- Document 3 states that Sentinel-1C was successfully launched in December 2024 and became fully operational in early May 2025, re-establishing the 2-satellite Sentinel-1 constellation configuration with Sentinel-1A and Sentinel-1C.

In summary, the Sentinel-1B satellite is no longer operational. The Sentinel-1 constellation was reduced to a single satellite (Sentinel-1A) for a period from September 2022 to April 2025, until the launch and commissioning of the new Sentinel-1C satellite, which has now joined Sentinel-1A to restore the 2-satellite Sentinel-1 constellation.
reference: No. The Sentinel-1B mission ended on August 3, 2022, following a power supply anomaly in December 2021.

user_input: Has the Sentinel-4 mission been launched? If so, on which platform?
retrieved_contexts:
['Document: S2 Mission
Section: S2 Mission > Overview of Sentinel-2 Mission > Satellite Description
Content:
The Sentinel-2 mission baseline consists of two identical satellites operating together, today Sentinel-2B (launched in 2017) and Sentinel-2C (launched in 2024) that were launched using the European VEGA launcher. Each of these satellites weighs approximately 1.2 tonnes.
As Sentinel-2A (launched in 2015) nears the end of its operational life after a decade, the launch of Sentinel-2C was critical for continuing the Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission. Sentinel-2C was launched on September 5th, 2024, and joined the other two satellites, starting to operate alongside Sentinel-2A to ensure seamless calibration and uninterrupted data collection.
Sentinel-2C has replaced Sentinel-2A in operation on January 21st, 2025, as announced [here](https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/-/precise-timing-of-transfer-of-duty-from-sentinel-2a-to-sentinel-2c-on-21-january), and Sentinel-2D will succeed Sentinel-2B. The mission will continue evolving with Sentinel-2 Next Generation, promising enhanced global measurements and continuity beyond 2035, securing essential Earth observation services.
Starting in March 2025, Sentinel-2A is performing an [extension campaign](https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/-/sentinel-2a-extended-campaign-starting-march-13-2025), exceptionally complementing the nominal two-satellites (Sentinel-2B/2C) mission constellation operations configuration. The campaign foresees the implementation of a tailored Sentinel-2A [operations scenario](https://sentiwiki.copernicus.eu/web/s2-mission#S2-Mission-Observation-Scenario).', "Document: S5P Mission
Section: S5P Mission > Overview of Sentinel-5P Mission > Satellite Description
Content:
Sentinel-5P is a low Earth-orbit satellite compatible with small launchers, including VEGA and ROCKOT, with ROCKOT being the selected launch vehicle. Sentinel-5P is designed for a seven year operational lifetime with 80 kg of hydrazine propellant.
The mechanical platform consists of a hexagonal structure supporting the platform electrical units and the TROPOMI Instrument Control Unit (ICU), and interfacing to a standard launch vehicle interface ring.
**The main subsystems of the satellite are:**
* propulsion subsystem (including a hydrazine tank)
* Electrical Power Subsystem (EPS), comprising three deployable solar arrays providing power to the spacecraft and payload
* Thermal Control Subsystem (TCS), including heaters needed to maintain the thermal environment on the platform
* Attitude and Orbit Control System (AOCS) composed of a three-head star tracker, GPS receivers, reaction wheels, magnetotorquers, a coarse Earth sensor and magnetometers
* Data Handling Subsystem (DHS), comprising the on-board computer with a mass memory of 72 hours for satellite housekeeping data and command storage for at least 7 days of operation
* S-band communication subsystem (TT&C), providing two redundant S-band transponders for reception of telecommands and transmission of satellite housekeeping data
* Payload Data Handling and Transmission subsystem (PDHT), providing a mass memory capacity for storage of 'science' telemetry and two redundant X-band transmitters.  
_Table 1: Main Satellite Platform Characteristics_
**Characteristic** | **Detail**
---|---
Bus | AstroBus L 250 M from Airbus Defence & Space
Attitude control | Three-axis stabilised with optional yaw steering
Launch mass | 820 kg. (including 82 kg fuel and TROPOMI instrument 220 kg)
Power | 1 500 W (EOL), 430 W average power consumption
Battery capacity | 156 Ah", 'Document: Ask Copernicus - AI data guide
Section: Ask Copernicus - AI data guide
Content:
*  
1. SentiWiki  
  
The Copernicus programme has been in operation since 2011, and the Sentinel missions provide extensive information and observations of Earth.
Over a decade since the launch of the first Sentinel satellite in 2014, a large amount of information and resources has been published on different websites.
Utilising the latest advances in technology, the European Environment Agency developed an AI chatbot to help find, understand, and use Copernicus data products.
Currently in Beta, the Observia AI platform, known as Ask Copernicus, is designed to search for information on trusted Copernicus sources, providing a reliable and helpful service and reducing manual browsing and searching.
If you need help with finding and downloading products, [Ask Copernicus](https://ask.copernicus.eu/).  

*  ](https://www.atlassian.com/software/confluence)', 'Document: Copernicus Programme
